overview: Insurance companies dispose of written off vehicles. If you want to scrap a vehicle yourself you need to take it to an authorised treatment facility
title: Scrapped and written off vehicles

table.body:
If your vehicle has been damaged and your insurance company writes your vehicle off, you'll need to hand the vehicle over to them to be disposed of.

If your vehicle isn’t written off but you still want to scrap it, you can take it to an authorised treatment facility (ATF).

If you break it up yourself, you’ll have to make a SORN (Statutory Off Road Declaration) or keep taxing it until you take it to an ATF.

*[ATF]: Authorised Treatment Facility
table.title: Overview

table.body:
If your insurance company decides to write off your vehicle, you'll need to hand the vehicle over to them to dispose of.

You’ll need to:

- complete the V5C/3 ‘Notification of sale or transfer’ section of your registration certificate and send it to **DVLA, Swansea, SA99 1BD**
- give the rest of the registration certificate to your insurance company

Your insurance company may ask you for the whole registration certificate. They’ll then complete it for you and send it to DVLA.

If this happens, write a letter with details of your insurance company and the date you gave them the vehicle. Send it to **DVLA, Swansea, SA99 1BR**.

If your vehicle doesn’t get scrapped and you want to keep the salvage, you should keep the V5C registration certificate.

If you want to repair the vehicle and put it back on the road you may need to take it for a [Vehicle Identity Check (VIC)](/vehicle-identity-check "Vehicle Identity Check (VIC)").

*[DVLA]: Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency
table.title: If your insurance company writes off your vehicle

table.body:
To scrap your vehicle you must take it to an [authorised treatment facility (ATF)](http://www.environment-agency.gov.uk/business/regulation/65470.aspx/ "authorised treatment facility (ATF)"){:rel="external"} who’ll make sure it’s dismantled in an environmentally friendly way.

##Cars, light vans and 3-wheeled vehicles

If the ATF agrees to scrap your vehicle they’ll give you a Certificate of Destruction (CoD) straight away if you’re scrapping a:

- car
- light van
- 3-wheeled motor vehicle (but not a motor tricycle)

The CoD is proof that the vehicle has been destroyed and you’re not responsible for it any more. The ATF will tell DVLA that you’re no longer responsible for the vehicle.

##Other types of vehicle

If you want to scrap any other type of vehicle you can still take it to an ATF, but you won’t get a CoD.

The ATF will tell DVLA, who will update the vehicle record to say it’s been destroyed. Then you should complete the V5C/3 ‘Notification of sale or transfer’ part of your V5C vehicle registration certificate and send it to **DVLA, Swansea, SA99, 1BD**.

You should get a letter saying you’re no longer responsible for the vehicle. If you don’t get this letter within 4 weeks, **phone 0300 790 6802 (textphone 0300 123 1279)**.

##If you’ve broken up the vehicle yourself

If you’ve broken up the vehicle yourself you must [make a SORN (Statutory Off Road Notification)](/register-sorn-statutory-off-road-notification "make a SORN (Statutory Off Road Notification)") or continue to tax the vehicle. 

You’ll have to make a SORN every year until you’ve taken it to an ATF or told DVLA you longer have it.

Tell DVLA by sending in your V5C/3 ‘Notification of sale or transfer’ part of your V5C vehicle registration certificate or writing a letter explaining you no longer have the vehicle. Send it to **DVLA, Swansea, SA99, 1BD**.

*[ATF]: Authorised Treatment Facility
*[CoD]: Certificate of Destruction
*[SORN]: Statutory Off Road Notification
*[DVLA]: Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency
table.title: Scrapping your vehicle

table.body:
If your vehicle has got a [personalised registration](/personalised-vehicle-registration-numbers "personalised registration"), you’ll have to transfer or retain it using form V317 before it gets scrapped.

^If you don’t, you’ll lose your entitlement to the personalised registration number.^

$D

[Download 'Application to transfer or retain a vehicle registration number (V317)' (PDF, 139KB).](http://www.direct.gov.uk/prod_consum_dg/groups/dg_digitalassets/@dg/@en/@motor/documents/digitalasset/dg_069390.pdf "Download 'Application to transfer or retain a vehicle registration number (V317)' (PDF, 139KB)"){:rel="external"}

$D

If your vehicle is being written off by your insurance company, you’ll need to tell them not to dispose of the vehicle until your personalised registration has been transferred or retained.

You should also ask them to make sure the vehicle is available for inspection.

You’ll also need to get a:

- letter of no interest from the insurers confirming they’re happy for you to transfer or retain the vehicle registration number
- copy of the engineer's report confirming the vehicle’s details
